Pellagra can be a serious illness and, if left untreated, it can cause severe complications. In its early stages, pellagra causes skin inflammation, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, dehydration, and abdominal pain. These symptoms are similar to other conditions, such as stomach flu, food poisoning, or even the common cold. If left untreated, the disease progresses to neurological problems, including confusion, dementia, seizures, and paralysis.

Varicose veins are enlarged, twisted and often painful veins. The most common location for varicose veins is the legs, but they can also occur in the thighs, pelvis, ankles and feet. Varicose veins are caused by a weakening of the valves within the vein, which allows blood to flow backward into the vein instead of up toward the heart. This results in increased pressure within the vein, causing it to swell and become more visible through the skin.

Varicose veins can be diagnosed during a physical exam by a medical professional. A doctor will feel the veins to determine if they are enlarged or twisted and may ask the patient to stand up so that he or she can observe the veins in a different position. An ultrasound is the most accurate way to diagnose varicose veins, because it shows the location of the veins and the extent of their disease. The doctor may also order an x-ray or blood test to rule out other conditions.

Varicose veins can cause a variety of symptoms. A person with varicose veins may experience aching, itching or burning in the legs. These veins may also be visible through the skin and appear as swollen, twisted, raised or bulging veins. The most common areas for varicose veins to develop are the legs and feet, but they can also occur on the face and neck.

Varicose veins can be treated with sclerotherapy, which involves injecting a chemical into the vein to cause it to collapse and disappear. Surgery is another option, but this is usually reserved for cases where other treatments have not worked.

Varicose veins can be hereditary, so if your family members have them, you are more likely to get them as well. Risk factors for developing varicose veins include being overweight, pregnancy and standing or sitting for long periods of time. Women are more likely than men to develop varicose veins, and they are also more likely to develop them during pregnancy.

Varicose veins are the most common venous disease and are often caused by increased pressure in the veins, which is a result of faulty valves that allow blood to flow backwards. A number of factors may contribute to this condition, including pregnancy, obesity and heredity. People with a family history of varicose veins are at higher risk for developing this condition.

The most common symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) include bloating, breast tenderness and fatigue. PMS is often accompanied by mood swings, depression, irritability, anxiety, food cravings and headaches. These symptoms usually occur about seven to 10 days before a woman's period begins and can last up to two weeks after her period starts.

PMS is diagnosed when the symptoms last for at least 7 days a month, and the symptoms are so severe that they interfere with daily activities. A medical professional may perform a pelvic examination to rule out other conditions that could be causing the symptoms, such as an ovarian cyst or endometriosis. Blood tests can also be used to check for thyroid disorders or hormonal imbalances, which can contribute to the symptoms of PMS.

There are several treatments that can be used to alleviate the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (PMS). These include diet, exercise and lifestyle changes. PMS is usually treated with a combination of dietary changes, lifestyle changes, and medications. The goal of treatment is to help manage symptoms, improve quality of life and prevent recurrences.

PMS is most common in women ages 25 to 45, but it can occur at any age. It is more likely to occur if you have a family history of the condition, if you are overweight or obese, if you smoke cigarettes, if you have high blood pressure or diabetes, and if you do not exercise regularly. Other risk factors include being under stress and taking certain medications, such as birth control pills, anti-depressants, antihistamines, antidepressants and beta blockers.

PMS is a term that refers to symptoms that occur before a woman's menstrual period. A woman may experience mood changes, fatigue, bloating and breast tenderness. These symptoms usually improve within a few days of the start of her period, but can last up to two weeks.

Premenstrual syndrome, or PMS, is a combination of physical, emotional and behavioral changes that many women experience in the days before their period begins. The exact cause of PMS is unknown, but it may be related to hormonal changes that occur during a woman's menstrual cycle. The most common symptoms include breast tenderness, bloating, mood swings and fatigue. There are many things that can be done to help manage these symptoms. These include eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly, getting enough sleep and managing stress. Women should also avoid foods and drinks that contain caffeine, as this can make symptoms worse. If these measures do not work, medications can be used to reduce symptoms.
